title: Maximum GCD on Whiteboard
statementHtml:
You are given an integer kk and nn positive integers a1,a2,…,ana1,a2,…,an written on a whiteboard, where 1≤ai≤n1≤ai≤n. You may perform the following operations:

The beauty of a collection of integers bb is defined as the greatest common divisor of all the elements in bb. Formally, it is the largest integer dd such that dd divides xx for every xx that is an element of bb.

Your task is to determine the maximum possible beauty of the integers on the whiteboard after performing at most kk Erase operations and any number of Split operations.
inputSpecHtml:
Each test contains multiple test cases. The first line contains the number of test cases tt (1≤t≤1041≤t≤104). The description of the test cases follows.

The first line of each test case contains two integers nn and kk (1≤n≤2⋅1051≤n≤2⋅105, 0≤k≤n−10≤k≤n−1) — the number of integers on the whiteboard, and the maximum number of Erase operations allowed.

The second line of each test case contains nn integers a1,a2,…,ana1,a2,…,an (1≤ai≤n1≤ai≤n) — the integers initially written on the whiteboard.

It is guaranteed that the sum of nn over all test cases does not exceed 2⋅1052⋅105.
outputSpecHtml: For each test case, output a single integer representing the maximum beauty of the elements written on the whiteboard after performing the operations.
noteHtml:
In the first test case, you may perform the following sequence of operations:

  • Erase 77. The whiteboard now contains the integers [4,9,6,8,2,6,8,2][4,9,6,8,2,6,8,2].
  • Split 99 into three integers 22, 33, and 44. 99 is erased from the whiteboard, and two new integers 22 and 44 are written. The whiteboard now contains the integers [4,2,4_,6,8,2,6,8,2][4,2,4––––,6,8,2,6,8,2].
  • Split 88 into three integers 22, 22, and 44. 88 is erased from the whiteboard, and two new integers 22 and 44 are written. The whiteboard now contains the integers [4,2,4,6,2,4_,2,6,8,2][4,2,4,6,2,4––––,2,6,8,2] (It does not matter which 88 Split is performed on as the ordering in the array does not matter).

The beauty of the integers on the whiteboard after the operations is 22 as it is the largest number that divides all the integers on the whiteboard (22, 44, 66, and 88). Note that the last operation is unnecessary — the beauty of the integers on the whiteboard after the second operation is already 22.

In the second test case, note that the Erase operation can only remove one occurrence of an integer, even if duplicates exist. Here, we are only able to erase one copy of 77, so there will still be one remaining 77 on the whiteboard. Hence, we are unable to perform the same sequence of operations as in the first test case.

In the third test case, we can erase integers 11, 11, 22, 33, and 44, leaving only [5,5][5,5] on the whiteboard. Since both numbers are 55, their greatest common divisor is 55, and the maximum beauty is 55.
